Author: bangaladore
Content: Just a heads up to everyone here who needs access to player info at longer ranges, as I said earlier, DayZ has a network bubble which means your client does not know anything about players more than ~1000 meters away from you. The reason why is say this is It was suggested to me by a couple people last night that simply sending the PlayerBase from the server to a client who wants to track a player is sufficient and allows you to grab a players position always. This is incorrect, however it does allow you to track a players position in realtime without the use of extensive RPCs (YAY for server performance) at distances less than the network bubble,  but the moment that player leaves the network bubble, all their information stops updating. @NiiRoZz

Author: mikero
Content:
folks, you are dealing with addons. In the bis engine. there's no such thing as c:\steam, c:\my documents or indeed c:\anything. The bis engine looks for *everything* starting at \

The \ is the root of  of a linux file system, and,  to emulate that you create a virtual drive. In dayz, that drive is popualarly called z:\ (in arma, it's the P:\  drive)

Every single addon you ever make is on that drive. No ifs, buts, or maybes.
and every single pbo YOU make should be in

Z:\mytag

z:\mytag is the place where no other person making an addon can collide with what you are doing. Thus:

z:\mytag\MyM16   is a different animal to

z:\hisTag\MyM16. there is no collission because the folder is different.

thus, you endup with:

z:\mytag\Mytank
z:\mytag\MyScripts
z:\mytag\MyRifle

And, usung pboProject or addon breaker, you end up with

myScripts.pbo
myRifle.pbo and, 
MyTank.pbo

-----

the same rules apply for bis.

schock and horror, guess what's inside

z:\Scripts
